pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.9: _Masāraka_. [Sp.2.111](): _Masārakoti mañcapāde vijjhitvā tattha aṭaniyo pavesetvā kato_, “_Masāraka_: it is made by making a hole in the legs of the bed and then inserting the rails of the frame there.” | _Bundikābaddha_. [Sp.2.111](): _Bundikābaddhoti aṭanīhi mañcapāde ḍaṁsāpetvā pallaṅkasaṅkhepena kato_, “_Bundikābaddha_: it is made by making the rails of the frame ‘biteʼ the legs of the bed, in the way of a luxurious bed (_pallaṅka_).” [Sp-yoj.1.111](): _Bundo eva bundiko, pādo, tasmiṁ ābaddhā bandhitā aṭanī yassāti bundikābaddho_, “_Bundikābaddha_: a _bundika_ is just a _bunda_, a leg; in that to which the rail is bound, attached.” | _Kuḷīrapādaka_. [Sp.2.111](): _Yo vā pana koci vaṅkapādako, ayaṁ vuccati kuḷīrapādako_, “Whatever has crooked legs, this is called a _kuḷīrapādaka_.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.11: See [](pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.9) for further explanations of these terms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.1.15: I have rendered _muñja_-reed and _pabbaja_-reed with the single word “reed”. I am not aware that these different species of reed can be properly distinguished in English.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc14:2.2.4: [Sp-yoj.1.112](): _Cammakhaṇḍoti ettha cammaṁyeva ante khaṇḍattā chinnattā cammakhaṇḍoti vuccati_, “Here _cammakhaṇḍa_ is just a hide. Because it is cut up within and made of pieces, it called a _cammakhaṇḍa_.”
